response.answer_text: Q. What is Science? (1) This answer is in the realm of Philosophy of science. (2) Science has been instrumental in many of humanity’s most momentous endeavors. Sent people to the moon.Created nukes.Gave women control over their fertility.The PCThe Internet(3) People have disagreed over what all these achievements tell us about the image of our world, that science reveals. Does science give us an accurate representation of how things, nature, the world, the universe, truly are?Or, does science instead offer us something of great importance, but something quite distinct from a true picture of the universe? Maybe a set of techniques for computing observations, or a series of detailed stories that, whether true or false, have earned their keep, through their remarkable practical value?(4) Let’s look at 3 possible views of science. (5) View #1: Scientific realism (5a) Simply… The goal of science is an account of the physical world that is literally true. Science is in the Truth business.Science represents those parts of the world it deals with in an increasingly accurate way over time. We understand our universe better and better over time.Science is not the only fount of knowledge. There is lots to learn from the Arts and the Humanities.Science is far from finished. Science continues to uncover the universe, refining and sharpening our images of nature.Science has been successful because this is the goal that it has been making progress towards.(5b) no-miracle argument This is the single, most popular argument to support Scientific Realism. No miracles, please. An analogy. You’re trying to navigate a ship through treacherous waters. Two scenarios. You made the effort to find out the whereabouts of the submerged rocks and sandbanks. You navigated safely through. If you hadn’t done your research, you would’ve likely smashed your ship.You didn’t do any research on the waters. In spite of your cluelessness, you were exceptionally fortunate to navigate safely through. A miracle!Apply the above to science. The waters → the universe.Your research on the waters → scientific theories on the universeNavigated safely through → Successful application of scientific theories e.g. applying physics laws to send people to the moonMiracle → The theory was actually wrong, but its application brought benefit to humanity → The physics laws were erroneous, but they got people to the moon anyway! Above: Hilary Putnam’s no-miracle argument (6) View #2: Scientific theories are tools Should we think of scientific theories in the same way we think of hammers or computers. They’re remarkably useful. But, they’re mere tools. It makes no sense to ask whether a hammer is true. Or, whether a hammer accurately represents the world. Is this the case for science too? We should simply ask whether its theories are fit for their purposes. (7) View #3: Do we care if science accurately reflects the universe, as long as it’s useful? A religious analogy. Some prominent Anglicans seem to think that the stories in the Bible are stimulating fictions, or maybe full-blown falsehoods, but we hold onto them because of the ways in which they help us navigate the world. The doctrine, the religion serves its flock. Newtonian mechanics was upended by Einstein. Newtonian mechanics sent people to the moon. Somewhat related: Sam Qwato's answer to Philosophy: What is C.S. Peirce's pragmatism? (8) More Philosophy of Science: Sam Qwato's answer to Regarding the scientific method, who was right, Thomas Kuhn or Karl Popper?

Science is a set of tools people used to build robust predictions. The tools are called The Scientific Method. (Some people prefer to say that Science creates explanations. That's fine. They are explanations in the form of predictions.) The first step is to come up with a falsifiable hypothesis. That's a claim which can, in theory, be proven wrong. The next step is to try to prove it wrong via careful observation and experimentation.  If you manage to falsify the hypothesis or are unable to falsify it, you will be able to use it to make predictions.  Here's a simple example: my hypothesis is that given a random sampling of New Yorkers, over 50% will prefer Coke to Pepsi in a blind taste test. That is falsifiable. It's possible that less-than 50% prefer Coke, and I can imagine ways of discovering that.  I attempt to falsify my claim by paying 1,000 New Yorkers, chosen at random, to try both Coke and Pepsi in unmarked cups. I make sure both test subjects and the people handing them the cups have no idea which cup contains Coke and which contains Pepsi.  That's called double-blind testing. It's one of many tools developed by scientists to try to make experiments as accurate as possible. Others include the use of control groups, the elimination of variables, etc.  Most of these tools are meant to mitigate human error. Science is a deeply-skeptical pursuit, and it assumes that if humans simply try to observe and reason--without the help of special tools and techniques--they will make all sorts of mistakes. For instance, if I know which cup contains Coke, I may unconsciously signal that to the test subjects. It's better if both they and I have no idea which beverage is in which cup. Let's say I discover that 80% prefer Coke. I then use that result to predict that if I try the same thing on another randomly selected group of New Yorkers, they too will prefer Coke at greater than 50%. The next part of the process is peer review. Scientists publish the results of their findings, the data they collected, and the methods the used, and let other scientists try to replicate their results.  The more repeated attempts lead to the same conclusions, the more robust the predictive power will be. Once the scientific community is convinced that New Yorkers prefer Coke to Pepsi, they can start using that prediction as a building block for other hypotheses. In other words, instead of "if X and Y, then New Yorkers prefer Coke to Pepsi," they can start saying, "Since New Yorkers prefer Coke to Pepsi, then ..." Which is how we slowly build up a web of useful predictions.  These often become useful outside of Science, in this case maybe in marketing. Often, engineers and manufacturers use the predictions Science has come up with, for instance when they build Mars rovers and drugs that cure various diseases.

response.answer_text: What is science?  Science is the concerted human effort to understand, or to understand better, the history of the natural world and how the natural world works, with observable physical evidence as the basis of that understanding1. It is done through observation of natural phenomena, and/or through experimentation that tries to simulate natural processes under controlled conditions. (There are, of course, more definitions of science.) Consider some examples. An ecologist observing the territorial behaviors of bluebirds and a geologist examining the distribution of fossils in an outcrop are both scientists making observations in order to find patterns in natural phenomena. They just do it outdoors and thus entertain the general public with their behavior. An astrophysicist photographing distant galaxies and a climatologist sifting data from weather balloons similarly are also scientists making observations but in more discrete settings. The examples above are observational science, but there is also experimental science. A chemist observing the rates of one chemical reaction at a variety of temperatures and a nuclear physicist recording the results of the bombardment of a particular kind of matter with neutrons are both scientists performing experiments to see what consistent patterns emerge. A biologist observing the reaction of a particular tissue to various stimulants is likewise experimenting to find patterns of behavior. These folks usually do their work in labs and wear impressive white lab coats, which seems to mean they make more money too. The critical commonality is that all these people are making and recording observations of nature, or of simulations of nature, in order to learn more about how nature, in the broadest sense, works. We'll see below that one of their main goals is to show that old ideas (the ideas of scientists a century ago or perhaps just a year ago) are wrong and that, instead, new ideas may better explain nature.

Science is the field of giving rigorous answers, but ironically the definition of "science" is itself not rigorous.  The field of "philosophy of science" is dedicated to trying to give an answer to the question. In school, they teach you about the scientific method: hypothesize, experiment, revise.  They don't teach you (generally) about the next step, publication.  Science is a human enterprise, conducted by fallible human beings, and for something to be science it has to be reviewed by other scientists.  This is obviously recursive and self-swallowing, not just in that it leaves open the "base case" of who is a scientist, but also in that peers who review the science are themselves human.  In that sense, science is itself as much art as science. And yet it muddles along.  We wouldn't be bothering to define science except that it's useful.  There's a lot of things that are clearly "science" and other things that are clearly "not science", and there's not a lot of controversy about that.  The peer review process is Good Enough. But that's not Good Enough for those who want a rigorous definition of science, and that opens a massive epistemological can of worms.  You'd really like a definition that says, "Chemistry is science, phrenology is not", but it turns out to be harder than you'd think.  There were great debates in the mid 20th century about whether something had to be "verifiable" (subject to an experiment that would confirm it) or "falsifiable" (subject to an experiment that could prove it false).  Both the verificationists (Vienna Circle and the Logical Positivists) and the falsificationists (Karl Popper) are subject to cases where their definitions either exclude a real science or include something widely considered pseudoscience. Then along comes Thomas Kuhn, who kind of swept both away with his theory of paradigm shift, moving away from science as an epistemological field to a more human enterprise.  He distinguishes between "normal" science, done in the current paradigm, and revolutions, which throw out the paradigm.   If you ask most scientists, they'll see their work in falsificationist terms, and that works well during both normal science and some revolutions.  Recent revolutions, such as quantum mechanics, have forced scientists to reconsider exactly what it means for something to be verified, since QM experiments are so fiendishly counterintuitive.   I've given only the barest outline of the debates, which are far more in-depth and complicated than I've given here.  It's a fascinating field, though, one that most elderly scientists end up turning their thoughts to at one time or another.

Science is a method (or tool) enabling the discovery of new observations, by the collation of data, development of models, and subsequent use of those models for prediction. Models themselves undergo change over time. I read the question Wiki with something approaching despair. It isn’t a collation of all the knowledge of one hundred plus answers, and doesn’t appear to contribute more than a naive personal, and cartoon like sketch of what one person considers science to be. How it is a Wiki, and not an answer staggers me. I will try to do more than a sketch, but what is a science is needs a little more explanation. There are (to my understanding) at least three ways for thinking about what constitutes a science: Science is a collection of ‘facts’ by observation (induction), which are then used to produce models that are a collation of our understanding. The key flaw with viewing science as purely induction, is the statistically small number of observations we can make, compared to a universe of potential data points. There is the possibility of being badly misled.Science is being practised if, and only if, the model utilised can be proved false (falsification). This view of science was pioneered by Karl Popper. As a model of what constitutes a science, it has the pragmatic advantage of directing experiments towards disproof of a theory, which ironically appears to expand our knowledge more rapidly than trying to shore up a theory with more and more facts. It does struggle a little with things that might be one off events, or broad sweep of scientific knowledge that don’t easily fit into a model that may be falsified overall.Thomas Kuhn came up with a different view in his book The Structure of Scientific Revolution , which saw science broken into the following phases:Lack of consensus, characterised by competing theories, and large bodies of knowledge that lack a unifying principle.Normal science, which takes a unifying principle, and works within that paradigm in order to shore up a model, or theory behind that principle.Crisis where anomalies are discovered that challenge the paradigm of normal science. At this point there is often heated disagreement concerning the significance of anomalies, and denial of their existence by those still engaging in normal science.Paradigm shift, where a new model or theory has won over the majority of the scientific community, forming a new unifying principle for normal science to predict.Post revolution, where preceding science is recast into the new paradigm, giving the impression of continuous progress rather than the fits and starts demonstrated by looking at the history of events.All of the above, regardless which description you prefer as a model, indicates a science to be a tool that allows us to discover new things. Sometimes it looks like a stamp collection of things considered ‘facts.’ Sometimes it looks like a way of discovering more of our models, by deliberately challenging them. Sometimes, and certainly in the longer sweep of history, it looks like people working according to a specific set of assumptions (paradigm). In the latter case this is conducted by very human people, who resist change, who require a tipping point of observations before considering any change, at which point they switch to a new model and act as though that new new model was understood throughout earlier collection of facts. This gives an impression of continuous progress that doesn’t actually match the flow of events. I suspect all these models hold something of the truth of what constitutes a science. If we try to shoe horn science into only one or other, then we will probably stumble into needing the others for completeness. What science is not might be as interesting as what it is. Science is not: An explanation for one-off events, that are not amenable to modelling or predictionA set of beliefs, even though practitioners may demonstrate some semblance to belief if their paradigm is challengedAn explanation of everything, with nothing yet to discover. If it were that, it’d no longer be a tool for discovery, and it wouldn’t need any further research.Holistically, I see science best summarised as per my opening paragraph: Science is a method (or tool) enabling the discovery of new observations, by the collation of data, development of models, and subsequent use of those models for prediction. Models themselves undergo change over time. As a closing note, it can be helpful to think about models. Models used in the sciences, are really a form of simulation. They are not truth in themselves. Maarten Steinbuch has posted the following statement about simulation to help focus the mind: Simulation is like masturbation: the more you do it, the more you think it is the real thing![1] Footnotes[1] Statements to remember on Theory and Practice

Science is a method for discovering truth. You and I are constantly trying to figure out truth through our senses, but often we can be tricked into believing something that’s false. Science applies the principles of logic to help us interpret what we observe. A basic example: A find a small box. What’s in the box? I have no idea. Let’s use science to find out! First, I look at the box and on the outside it says “24K gold ingot”. This is my first piece of data. It gives me a solid clue of what might be in the box. Is this a very good clue? It depends. If I were inside a bank vault, it would suggest there really is gold in the box. But if I were in a theater prop store, I would _logically_ assume it was probably fake. In one case, I would be more sure than the other, but I’m not _completely_ sure. How can I be more sure? I need another observation. This time I lift the box. It’s very heavy. Logically, this is exactly what I expect because gold is a dense, heavy metal. Now I have two observations that agree with the gold “hypothesis.” I’m starting to get excited. I’m still not totally sure, so I need yet another observation. Now I actually open the box. Inside I can see a small brick of shiny yellow metal that definitely looks like gold. I have three confirming observations. This is enough that I now I feel confident try to sell it at a gold shop. There are some important things to notice about the above story that will help you understand science: At every point in the story, I am becoming more and more convinced that the truth is that there really is gold in the box.But: at any point in the story I could also make an observation that would prove there was not gold after all. The box could have been light. Or I could have seen a big rock when I opened it. I could have been 99% sure there was gold one moment and 0% sure then next.I am never 100% sure. Even after the 3rd observation, I will need more evidence if I hope to sell it. The gold dealer will perform even more tests to make sure it is pure gold before she gives me money.This is the nature of science. We make more and more observations, building up a case for the truth until we are proved otherwise. A true scientist is always open to being proved false, because that is the way truth is discovered. I want to stress here that scientific method can never get us to a 100% sure way of understanding truth. At the foundation of science is a logical principle that is based on probability. It is called “Occam’s Razor”, and it says that given two explanations for a thing, the simplest explanation is most likely to be correct. Every scientific conclusion, discovery, or theory is ultimately based on this principle. This may seem like a weakness, and it is, but we must remember that in spite of this weakness, science has been spectacularly successful at advancing our knowledge and technology. This is because we have been relentlessly pushing our observations so that if we can’t be 100% sure, we can at least be 99.9999% sure. The lesson is that science is wonderful and powerful, but it’s not scientific to ever be absolutely sure.

This question has spawned an entire discipline: Philosophy of science; and its more rigorous form is known as the demarcation problem[1], i.e., how to differentiate science from non-science (which includes, but is not limited to, metaphysics, religion, and pseudoscience). Unfortunately, we don’t have a clear cut definition of the term. What we have are different schools of philosophical thoughts. Thus, there is the “logical positivism” of the Vienna and Berlin circles, which holds that scientific statements should be verifiable. There is the “falsification” of Karl Popper, requiring that scientific theories should ideally be falsifiable (and not just verifiable). There is Thomas Kuhn’s “post-positivism,” which emphasizes that a scientific paradigm is useful only insofar as it is successful in solving new puzzles while continuing to provide solutions for older problems. Surprisingly, there are those who believe that demarcation problem is ultimately an unsolvable epistemic dilemma. Even so, my favorite discourse on the nature of science was written almost five centuries ago by none other than Francis Bacon, which — though less precise and a bit more wishy-washy than the theses of Popper and Kuhn — is infinitely more enjoyable to read. Bacon compared science to the legendary Sphinx — a part-human, part-animal creature which dwelt on the summit of a mountain near Thebes and posed a riddle to wayward travelers, killing them if they answered wrongly. Only Oedipus managed to solve the riddles successfully and vanquish the monster, winning the kingship of Thebes as a reward. Here is what Bacon writes: Science, being the wonder of the ignorant and unskilful, may be not absurdly called a monster. In figure and aspect it is represented as many-shaped, in allusion to the immense variety of matter with which it deals. It is said to have the face and voice of a woman, in respect of its beauty and facility of utterance. Wings are added because the sciences and the discoveries of science spread and fly abroad in an instant; the communication of knowledge being like that of one candle with another, which lights up at once. Claws, sharp and hooked, are ascribed to it with great elegance, because the axioms and arguments of science penetrate and hold fast the mind, so that it has no means of evasion or escape; a point which the sacred philosopher also noted: The words of the wise are as goads, and as nails driven deep in. Again, all knowledge may be regarded as having its station on the heights of mountains; for it is deservedly esteemed a thing sublime and lofty, which looks down upon ignorance as from an eminence, and has moreover a spacious prospect on every side, such as we find on hill-tops. It is described as infesting the roads, because at every turn in the journey or pilgrimage of human life, matter and occasion for study assails and encounters us. Again Sphinx proposes to men a variety of hard questions and riddles which she received from the Muses. In these, while they remain with the Muses, there is probably no cruelty; for so long as the object of meditation and inquiry is merely to know, the understanding is not oppressed or straitened by it, but is free to wander and expatiate, and finds in the very uncertainty of conclusion and variety of choice a certain pleasure and delight; but when they pass from the Muses to Sphinx, that is from contemplation to practice, whereby there is necessity for present action, choice, and decision, then they begin to be painful and cruel; and unless they be solved and disposed of, they strangely torment and worry the mind, pulling it first this way and then that, and fairly tearing it to pieces. Moreover the riddles of the Sphinx have always a twofold condition attached to them; distraction and laceration of mind, if you fail to solve them; if you succeed, a kingdom. For he who understands his subject is master of his end; and every workman is king over his work.[2]  Francis Bacon (1561–1626) Footnotes[1] Demarcation problem - Wikipedia[2] XXVIII. Sphinx; Or Science. Bacon, Francis. Of the Wisdom of the Ancients. 1857

Science is about determining the difference between reality and imagination. The funny thing is that this is so because science is made up of the assembled fragments that are formed by the creation and elimination of imagination itself as it renders reality.  Science is an agricultural affair. It begins with observations made in a set of circumstances - like a seed in soil.  From this first formant we develop hypotheses in harmony like a chord across keys. This are the sprouts of the seedling.  A solution to the problem of scale Then, as the tender tendrils exit their initial imaginative environment they are tested by the context into which they creep. Some will wither. Some won’t.  A decision tree Of those that flourish (as subsequent successes in trials centralise their structure) a fractal formation proceeds. What begins as only one branch may bear fruit thirty, sixty or a hundred times over.  Yes. Broccoli is a fractal. Now, every branch that does not bear fruit is pruned. It has no place in the ongoing process. Furthermore, the process produces its own procedure such that every fruit contains a new seed. In this way, deduction down to the most optimised vehicle acts as an ark that allows a new set of circumstances to induce a new stem.  Neuronal plasticity is promoted by this perpetual practice So, science is the objective of ontology - the certain knowledge that emerges from the rigorous refinement of renderings of reality. It is the marble which makes itself before being hewn by its own heuristics such that every fragment forms a future foundation. Some will never be built upon. Others will become the cornerstones and capstones of complete constructions. The beauty is that there is no end. Seasons come and go and everything has its place but the stuff of science endures eternally. It is the emergent activity of all actuality incarnate in intelligence. Simple isn’t it? All sewn up. Just one question: Where do we start?

Great question. Even though we often say we are living in the age of science, the word is often poorly understood and misused. Wikipedia's science (disambiguation) page makes it clear why the term might mean different things to different people. Instead of dealing with all the various meanings, let's look at the sort of science that gives us things like telecommunications, computers and space exploration. That kind of science is a disciplined, rule-based method for organizing information about how the world around us, and the universe it is in, actually work. It's a method for developing and refining a model that maps increasingly well to observed reality. Science currently deals with all the issues listed in the illustration below, and as the Scale of the Universe index on the left indicates, future improvements in our ability to observe at the very small and very large scale may extend what we are able to model.  How does that kind of science work? It uses the scientific method to refine. alter, expand or reject hypotheses. The steps of the scientific method are outlined below. Once a scientist has run though this entire process and it appears that the hypothesis is valid, s/he writes up all the steps in detail and submits it to a peer-reviewed journal for publication. Other scientists around the world look at the work and try to spot errors in methods or incorrect conclusions of observations. They duplicate the testing process to see if they get the same results. They think about whether some alternative explanation might better describe why the results were obtained. Only ideas that survive this rigorous review process become accepted theories, and even afterward, scientists continue to look for ways the theory might be improved or refined to yield and even more accurate mapping of observable results.  The above process is often slow and laborious, but it is the best method human beings have yet discovered to systematically increase our actual understanding of how "life, the Universe and everything" actually works.

Logical positivism, better known by its common name ‘science’, is the philosophy that what is verifiable empirically is what is cognitively meaningful to us - or in other, less precise terms, that what can be demonstrated in experiment is what we should hold to be ‘true’. Science in the modern age is exemplified not by the set of facts which we currently believe to be most accurate, but rather by the methodology by which we derive such ‘facts’ from our observations of the natural world. Of course, that seems like a rather obscure answer - does one really gain an understanding of science if it is explained as a methodology used to derive ‘facts’? Allow me to elaborate: The model of scientific progress is empirical in nature, and thus focuses primarily on the phenomena of the natural world. It relies on the following process to produce its results, the most striking of which is the device we’re using to communicate right now - a computer; observations of (anomalous) phenomena -> the formulation of hypotheses which propose to explain the observed data -> experiments which have the potential to falsify the hypotheses in question -> more observations about the outcome of the experiment. These secondary observations lead scientists to formulate new hypotheses to replace the falsified ones as well as to propose new experiments which could yet falsify those hypotheses which proceeded uncontested through our previous tests. This process produces functional and pragmatic utility because it rejects every explanation which fails to maintain consistency with our observations of the natural world, and thereby it ensures that those which triumph over time are those models which have predictive accuracy. The accuracy to which I refer becomes obvious when we succeed in creating combustion engines to make cars run, or jet engines combined with modern aerodynamic engineering which enables planes to fly - the models which inform our designs must share something in common with the truth of our environment, or such results would be impossible. Over the course of history, natural philosophers have produced many interpretations of the world, yet none have proved as useful in our efforts to manipulate our environment as science; there is clearly something about this reductive, naturalistic approach that enables us to progress towards our goals with an effectiveness that is unprecedented and unparalleled. Science may never produce an absolute truth, mostly because such a thing is unattainable from the subjective perspective we inherently inhabit, yet nonetheless, it represents our best guess yet at a formula, limited as it may be, for truth. How does science work, one might ask? Consistency. Consistency with what, my good man? Ah, now that is the question. Good luck - it’s an enigma, to be sure.

Image: "Sniffing" bees trained for security at Los Alamos National Laboratory. Credit: LANL Science is a systematic and logical approach to discovering how things in the universe work. It is also the body of knowledge accumulated through the discoveries about all the things in the universe. The word "science" is derived from the Latin word scientia, which is knowledge based on demonstrable and reproducible data, according to the Merriam-Webster Dictionary. True to this definition, science aims for measurable results through testing and analysis. Science is based on fact, not opinion or preferences. The process of science is designed to challenge ideas through research. One important aspect of the scientific process is that it is focuses only on the natural world, according to the University of California. Anything that is considered supernatural does not fit into the definition of science. The scientific method When conducting research, scientists use the scientific method to collect measurable, empirical evidence in an experiment related to a hypothesis(often in the form of an if/then statement), the results aiming to support or contradict a theory. "As a field biologist, my favorite part of the scientific method is being in the field collecting the data," Jaime Tanner, a professor of biology at Marlboro College, told Live Science. "But what really makes that fun is knowing that you are trying to answer an interesting question. So the first step in identifying questions and generating possible answers (hypotheses) is also very important and is a creative process. Then once you collect the data you analyze it to see if your hypothesis is supported or not." The steps of the scientific method go something like this: Make an observation or observations.Ask questions about the observations and gather information.Form a hypothesis — a tentative description of what's been observed, and make predictions based on that hypothesis.Test the hypothesis and predictions in an experiment that can be reproduced.Analyze the data and draw conclusions; accept or reject the hypothesis or modify the hypothesis if necessary.Reproduce the experiment until there are no discrepancies between observations and theory. "Replication of methods and results is my favorite step in the scientific method," Moshe Pritsker, a former post-doctoral researcher at Harvard Medical School and CEO of JoVE, told Live Science. "The reproducibility of published experiments is the foundation of science. No reproducibility – no science."Some key underpinnings to the scientific method: The hypothesis must be testable and falsifiable, according to North Carolina State University. Falsifiable means that there must be a possible negative answer to the hypothesis.Research must involve deductive reasoning and inductive reasoning. Deductive reasoning is the process of using true premises to reach a logical true conclusion while inductive reasoning takes the opposite approach.An experiment should include a dependent variable (which does not change) and an independent variable (which does change).An experiment should include an experimental group and a control group. The control group is what the experimental group is compared against.Scientific theories and laws The scientific method and science in general can be frustrating. A theory is almost never proven, though a few theories do become scientific laws. One example would be the laws of conservation of energy, which is the first law of thermodynamics. Dr. Linda Boland, a neurobiologist and chairperson of the biology department at the University of Richmond, Virginia, told Live Science that this is her favorite scientific law. "This is one that guides much of my research on cellular electrical activity and it states that energy cannot be created nor destroyed, only changed in form. This law continually reminds me of the many forms of energy," she said. A law just describes an observed phenomenon, but it doesn't explain why the phenomenon exists or what causes it. "In science, laws are a starting place," said Peter Coppinger, an associate professor of biology and biomedical engineering at the Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology. "From there, scientists can then ask the questions, 'Why and how?'" Laws are generally considered to be without exception, though some laws have been modified over time after further testing found discrepancies. This does not mean theories are not meaningful. For a hypothesis to become a theory, rigorous testing must occur, typically across multiple disciplines by separate groups of scientists. Saying something is "just a theory" is a layperson's term that has no relationship to science. To most people a theory is a hunch. In science, a theory is the framework for observations and facts, Tanner told Live Science.

(Those are climate cycles seen in ancient rock, typically 23,000 and 1,000,000 year periods.)  I told him that although I had not studied the field, I had grave doubts about the reality of those cycles.  He said that he did not want to start a project about which I was dubious, but I told him that I wasn't sure. Here is the fascinating point, one that I realized when we began the seminar.  He and I knew -- we really knew -- that at the end of the semester, we would be in agreement.  We didn't know if we would accept the Milankovitch theory, or if we would reject it (or somewhere in between) but we knew we would agree.  That's because it was a scientific question.   At the end of the semester, we were in agreement.  The Milankovitch theory was basically correct, but some details needed further study. I wound up spending the next ten years of my life investigating those details, writing numerous papers, and writing a major technical book on the subject. Logical positivism, better known by its common name ‘science’, is the philosophy that what is verifiable empirically is what is cognitively meaningful to us - or in other, less precise terms, that what can be demonstrated in experiment is what we should hold to be ‘true’. Science in the modern age is exemplified not by the set of facts which we currently believe to be most accurate, but rather by the methodology by which we derive such ‘facts’ from our observations of the natural world. Of course, that seems like a rather obscure answer - does one really gain an understanding of science if it is explained as a methodology used to derive ‘facts’? Allow me to elaborate: The model of scientific progress is empirical in nature, and thus focuses primarily on the phenomena of the natural world. It relies on the following process to produce its results, the most striking of which is the device we’re using to communicate right now - a computer; observations of (anomalous) phenomena -> the formulation of hypotheses which propose to explain the observed data -> experiments which have the potential to falsify the hypotheses in question -> more observations about the outcome of the experiment. These secondary observations lead scientists to formulate new hypotheses to replace the falsified ones as well as to propose new experiments which could yet falsify those hypotheses which proceeded uncontested through our previous tests. This process produces functional and pragmatic utility because it rejects every explanation which fails to maintain consistency with our observations of the natural world, and thereby it ensures that those which triumph over time are those models which have predictive accuracy. The accuracy to which I refer becomes obvious when we succeed in creating combustion engines to make cars run, or jet engines combined with modern aerodynamic engineering which enables planes to fly - the models which inform our designs must share something in common with the truth of our environment, or such results would be impossible. Over the course of history, natural philosophers have produced many interpretations of the world, yet none have proved as useful in our efforts to manipulate our environment as science; there is clearly something about this reductive, naturalistic approach that enables us to progress towards our goals with an effectiveness that is unprecedented and unparalleled. Science may never produce an absolute truth, mostly because such a thing is unattainable from the subjective perspective we inherently inhabit, yet nonetheless, it represents our best guess yet at a formula, limited as it may be, for truth.

Science is the concerted human effort to understand, or to understand better, the history of the natural world and how the natural world works, with observable physical evidence as the basis of that understanding. It is done through observation of natural phenomena, and/or through experimentation that tries to simulate natural processes under controlled conditions. (There are, of course, more definitions of science.)       Consider some examples. An ecologist observing the territorial behaviors of bluebirds and a geologist examining the distribution of fossils in an outcrop are both scientists making observations in order to find patterns in natural phenomena. They just do it outdoors and thus entertain the general public with their behavior. An astrophysicist photographing distant galaxies and a climatologist sifting data from weather balloons similarly are also scientists making observations, but in more discrete settings.       The examples above are observational science, but there is also experimental science. A chemist observing the rates of one chemical reaction at a variety of temperatures and a nuclear physicist recording the results of bombardment of a particular kind of matter with neutrons are both scientists performing experiments to see what consistent patterns emerge. A biologist observing the reaction of a particular tissue to various stimulants is likewise experimenting to find patterns of behavior. These folks usually do their work in labs and wear impressive white lab coats, which seems to mean they make more money too.       The critical commonality is that all these people are making and recording observations of nature, or of simulations of nature, in order to learn more about how nature, in the broadest sense, works. We'll see below that one of their main goals is to show that old ideas (the ideas of scientists a century ago or perhaps just a year ago) are wrong and that, instead, new ideas may better explain nature.

In semi-casual conversation, “science” can mean two things: either the discipline of investigating things via the scientific method, or the knowledge one gains from such investigations. The core of the scientific method is to elevate empirical evidence over anything else. You start with a question… for example how does so-and-so work? Then you guess at an answer. Then you determine whether your guess is consistent with empirical evidence. Or in a little more detail, you design an experiment that will at least potentially falsify your guess. Ideally, this is an experiment that has never been done before, so your guess involves a genuine prediction. If not, there’s at least the chance that you’ve implicitly “baked in” existing knowledge to your guess, so the experiment will necessarily be consistent with it. In any case, if your guess doesn’t agree with the experiment, it’s wrong. If it does agree with the experiment, that doesn’t necessarily mean it’s right. It’s just “not yet wrong,” as Feynman liked to say. But yeah, if a statement is consistent with tons and tons and tons of experiments, we start to get pretty high confidence that the statement is correct. That confidence can get so high that, as a practical matter, we consider that principle to be “proven,” even if it’s not technically incontrovertible. The collection of those principles that we have a high confidence in is also called “science.” Speaking even more casually, sometimes people use “science” to just refer to any body of knowledge, especially intricate knowledge, whether it comes from the scientific method or not. E.g., one might refer to “the art and science of playing the piano.”

Science is ancient, about 2500 years old, at least for us in the West (Eastern scientific traditions exist, as well). Karl Popper argued that for something to be a scientific claim then there had to be a way to test that claim that would show that it was false. Thomas Kuhn observed that scientists mostly do “normal science,” which involves measuring things and comparing them to theory, until we come across a discrepancy. We start to pick at the discrepancy, and eventually we have a scientific revolution. There have been many scientific revolutions, from Gallileo’s description of the pendulum, to Newton’s laws of motion, to Maxwell’s equations of electro-magnetism, to Einstein’s descriptions of the photo-electric effect, Brownian motion, and his theories of relativity, to the discoveries of dark matter and dark energy. Q: What is science actually? Science is the relentless application of common sense to questions about how the world works. If you want to figure out how the world works, here’s a good way to go about it: Collect people’s ideas and publish them, for all to see and criticize.Decide whether ideas are good or bad based on the outcome of demonstrations (“experiments”). And publish the results.Encourage other people to try and reproduce the results. If they fail, encourage them to publish about their inability to reproduce the result.When there are multiple ideas about the same thing works, apply common sense: choose the idea that applies to the widest number of situations and makes the fewest random underlying assumptions.Write the best ideas down in books. Toss out the ideas that don’t work so well.The ability of human beings to follow guidelines like these is mixed at best. People get hung up on their own ideas. More generally, they get hung up on the things they are taught and find it difficult to adapt to change. Sometimes even highly-trained and well-intentioned scientists go off on wild digressions that don’t adhere to these guidelines at all. But experience has shown that over time, following these guidelines gets the best answers to questions about how the world works. More effective ideas often lead to better technologies, which means people who follow the guidelines are more effective at dealing with the world than people who don’t over the long term. And since reality is competitive and sometimes harsh, this in turn means groups of people who follow the guidelines often replace groups of people who don’t.

So I see three schools of thought here: Science as method (I think this began with Descartes but really only achieved this form with Locke et al) Science as an uncertain theoretical system (models) which explains and includes the results of the method (Thomas Kuhn) and science as a certain theoretical system which embraces the product of the method as something a) known in some way and b) capable of being used as a steady basis for induction. This last seems to match up with the work of Michael Augros and the Institute for the Study of Nature: http://www.isnature.org/Files/Augros_Reconciling_Science_Philosophy.htm I find the first least convincing. If you could teach a monkey to perform experiments as a lab assistant, the monkey isn't "doing science", it isn't observing and noting conclusions. The one "doing science" is the one observing and taking notes and making inferences. In this sense science is the act of collecting, correlating and interpreting data, if it is an act.  But suppose you could teach a computer to collect like data, and spit out a working model. Is the computer a scientist? Not if it isn't a strong AI, since the computer has no actual notion of what it's doing in a weak AI context, it's just a very clever puppet. So under normal circumstances, we have only one being really "doing science", the human observer. But if we have now moved back behind the method to the one performing it, in what does science consist? In the one observing the method having been carried out. In other words, to do science is to observe the result of the scientific method and interpret it in a way yielding a crystallized view of the regularity of things in the physical world. But it is not enough to stop at saying "this always happens." If we stopped there science would, as the green Moon people say, be like magic. The second one is interesting, but it presumes a lot. So we say, okay, we need a systematic explanation of these observations. But we try to make one, and it falls apart. Then we say, we need another, and it falls apart. Now we could have two sorts of responses: someday we could find the actual model, or all our models must be imperfect approximations. But if science is supposed to be everything we know about the cosmos, and the cosmos is all there is, etc, then I hate to say it, but certainty about anything becomes impossible. We could all just be being fooled by the true conceptual model, namely, a clever space demon controlling our minds to make us think we are getting closer to the reality in our approximations. So even to say that what we see are anything but illusions of illusions of illusions ad infinitum, even like Russian nesting dolls, we have to (gasp!) step outside the mode we have of studying the physical universe into the question of our most general principles and into whether we can know what is closest to us with certainty. In other words, science not only depends on philosophy, it braces itself on it like a man on a life raft in the Pacific. It is thus interesting to me how people answer this.

Science goes hand in hand with statistics. There are varying levels of robustness when practicing science. This p value is likely to be very weak if I did (for example) 1 correct guess in a total of 4 trials. But if I did 250 correct guesses out of a total of 1,000 trials, it would imply that there is definitely something more than random chance happening (either I have ESP, or the experiment was designed in a way that allowed me to cheat). I believe a lot of people who believe in mysticism and pseudoscience can greatly benefit from an education on these simple statistics concepts.

Science is fundamentally a method for determining what is and isn't true. You observe the world, you come up with a hypothesis to explain what you see, and you perform experiments and/or make more observations to see if your explanation still holds up. If it does - despite repeated testing, preferably by a number of different people - then eventually it gets accepted enough to warrant the title of “theory.” Your explanation is never considered “proven” - despite a popular misconception, science isn't in the business of proving things; everything always has to remain open to question, to be challenged, and - should an explanation which better fits the evidence be found - you always have to be willing to dump your pet belief and move on. And the important thing to keep in mind is that this method, if honestly followed, works better than anything else we've ever come up with. Which is not to say that scientists don't get things wrong from time to time; obviously they do, sometimes spectacularly. But the method itself, over the long term, is self-correcting because of that “always question everything” part. Science has a fantastic record of converging to the right answers, time and time again.

We'll, there's an ancient meaning, and a modern meaning. I'll address the modern meaning first. Unfortunately, this won't be a rigorous definition, but I can point you to the Wikipedia page for the scientific method for more information.  In the modern context (for approximately 3/4 century), science is “the study of physical processes (called phenomena) through the use of the scientific method.” Applying this to energy, space, and time, we get physics. Applying this to life, we get biology. There are many more foci for science when used in this context. So, the scientific method works as a filter, using positivism (that which can be measured) to permit phenomena which we can apply, and verificationism (that which produces accurate prediction) to filter the results of observations. We leave the interpretations of said results to philosophy, but use the results themselves to generate models. More specifically, the scientific method works like this: formulate a conjecture, make a prediction (hypothesis), devise repeatable experiments to test said prediction, analyse the results, and throw out hypotheses that fail to predict the results. This means, we will always be revising the working hypotheses (which we call theories).  On to the original definition, and why it's important. Science originally meant “knowledge”. More specifically, it was the culmination of knowledge for a specific discipline. This is important if you ever talk about the formal sciences, computer science, political science, and when people talk about things like astrology as a science (nowadays, astrology is a pseudoscience according to modern definitions). So, care when the word science gets used around you to know what the speaker meant, AND whether or not they know about the definitions at all.

Science is the accumulation of independently verifiable facts about the world connected into a coherent framework of consistent principles. Different branches of science favor different organizing principles. The "hard sciences" (physics especially) favors quantitative measures of nature that can be expressed in terms of mathematical equations. Biology was once about cataloging the diversity of life, although with molecular biology, the focus has shifted to the discovery of mechanisms underlying the physiological functioning of life. Neuroscience, as a branch of biology, catalogs the diversity of phenomena and searches for underlying mechanisms. Psychology and the social sciences search for principles underlying the human condition, both individually and collectively. To gain greater legitimacy within the larger project of science, the social sciences have been moving towards greater use of quantitative measures and experimental methods. Engineering is different from science in that it emphasizes building (construction) rather than the discovery of natural properties and principles (deconstruction). Medicine is different from science in that it focuses on the treatment of physiological suffering. However in these days of evidence-based medicine, scientific principles have become the foundation of medical knowledge.  History is different from science in that it organizes events from the human social past into a framework that emphasizes meaning and understanding rather than quantitative principles. And the list goes on...

The work and the method of scientific thought is to formulate principles and undertake research without reference to God, so that a system of thought from which God is absent becomes the axis on which scientific work turns, causing man to be alienated from whatever lies beyond the scope of that thought. At the same time, man's practical life is inevitably connected with the sciences. The results yielded by empirical knowledge embrace all the material aspects of life, imprisoning man within their four impenetrable walls, and it is hardly possible to find any natural tool among the means of man's life. This necessarily increases man's trust in the sciences and affects his behavior, inducing in him a state of doubt and hesitation. In addition, the beneficial nature of the phenomena investigated by empirical science is tangible and aware to everyone, in sharp contrast to metaphysical questions. Similarly, the material phenomena investigated by empirical science are well-known, whereas the opposite is true in the case of metaphysics. The presentation of religious questions in the incorrect method followed by the medieval church, combined with enmity to all manifestations of science, was the most important factor in making empirical science appear preferable to philosophical and meta- physical concerns. In short, science appeared to be opposed to religion, not parallel to it. Once empirical logic succeeded in pouring all thoughts into its own mould, it colored men's outlook on the world to such a degree that they were convinced that it was the only basis for accepting the truth of a thing. They assigned it supreme authority and considered it impossible to prove the existence of anything imperceptible to the senses. So the empirical scientist, who is unaware of the method of those who know God, accepts and regards as proper, in the course of his life, whatever is compatible with scientific logic and thought. He grants himself the right to deny whatever is incompatible with his scientific method. His method is absolute trust in the experiment and regarding it as the sole proof for the correctness of any deduction. In such a situation, when the whole basis of religious thought is ignored, the scientist finds himself without any principles for interpreting those secondary religious questions which appear in the form of commands and prohibitions. Being totally accustomed to the language of science and dependent on formulae, he is utterly committed to his own method and imagines the binding, simple and straightforward commands of religion to be without content or value. This manner of thought is faulty and incorrect. Although the sciences have complex and extraordinarily precise formulae, the comprehension of which requires profound and difficult study, those same formulae leave the realm of science once they enter our practical lives, distancing themselves from the technical language of the scientists. Were this not to be the case, they would be restricted to scientific and industrial centers, libraries and centers of research. Everyone can make use of such facilities as the telephone and the radio. The same holds true of all scientific tools and instruments. For all their precision and complexity, a little specialized instruction will enable anyone to use them. The specialist and the expert do not pass on their mechanical, technical knowledge to the purchasers of the device; instead, they summarize in a few short sentences the result of the toils endured by the inventors. It is, therefore, unfair and incompatible with scientific logic to attempt to force the commands of religion (which cannot be compressed into a scientific formula, being both simple and universal) into the mould of one's own incorrect prejudices and imaginings, and then pronounce them worthless and insignificant, while ignoring their decisive role and their profound effects in our life. Practical instructions bear their fruit when they are proclaimed in a generally comprehensible language and become tangible for everyone in individual and social life. Furthermore, if it were supposed that the commands and instructions of religions should be determined by our cognition, understanding and taste, there would be no need for revelation and Prophets; we could construct our own religions. Man often overlooks his weaknesses, preoccupied as he is with his strengths. The science worshipper of the contemporary world is so proud of his knowledge as a result of the progress that has been attained in the experimental sciences that he imagines himself to have conquered and triumphantly taken possession of the world of truth. But nobody has ever been able to claim that he has attained knowledge of all the mysteries of the universe and removed all the veils from the world of nature. One must take a broader view of reality and realize how slight is one's own drop of knowledge when compared to the ocean of hidden mysteries that confronts us. In the wake of every scientific discovery, a further series of unknowns comes into view. Throughout the centuries that man has untiringly labored with all his resources to know the world as fully as possible, the only result of his exertions has been the discovery of a few among the many mysteries of the universe. Only a few short steps have been taken on this path, and there is a whole mass of unknowns clustered around human knowledge like a cloud. One must, therefore, assess more realistically the cognitive scope of the sensory sciences and their proper area of activity and influence. All preconceptions that are like barriers on the path to truth must be discarded in favor of a correct analysis. Without doubt, the empirical sciences can inform us only of the external aspects of phenomena; it is only matter and material phenomena that come within the scope of their study and are susceptible to laboratory experimentation. The method of the sciences in attaining their goal, while seeking to benefit from each slight increment in knowledge, is observation and experiment. Since the fundamental concern of the empirical sciences is the investigation of the external world, in order to be sure that a certain scientific theory is correct, we must compare it with the external world to test it. If the external world effectively verifies it, we accept it; if it does not, we do not accept it. So, considering the object and the method of the empirical sciences, we must ask whether metaphysical truths are subject to sensory test and experimentation? Does any empirical enquiry have the right to intervene in matters of faith and belief? Is any part of the experimental sciences concerned with God? To discover the correctness or incorrectness of a matter in the empirical sciences, it is necessary to make use of change and of the elimination of given factors and circumstances. This method is not applicable to the eternal, immutable and supra-material divine existence. Material knowledge is a lamp that can illumine certain unknown matters with its rays but it is not a lamp that can eliminate all darkness. For the knowledge of a system is dependent on comprehension of the whole in its totality and a form of cognition that can unite all partial insights in itself, resulting in a total vision. Now, to imprison human knowledge in the narrow, restrictive confines of the sensory sciences cannot bring man to a total vision, but only to an awareness of empirical phenomena combined with an unawareness of the inner dimension of being. Whether we believe in God or not has, in fact, no connection with the empirical sciences, because since the object of their investigations is matter, the sciences that concern themselves with material phenomena do not have the right to express themselves affirmatively or negatively concerning any non-material subject. According to the belief of religious schools of thought, God is not a body. He cannot be perceived by the senses. He transcends time and place. He is a being Whose existence is not subject to temporal limitation and place cannot restrict him. He is, therefore, free of need and exalted in His essence above any kind of deficiency. He knows the inner as well as the outer aspect of the universe; the world lies open before Him. Finally, He possesses the highest degree of every perfection and is loftier than whatever concerning Him might come to man's mind. We cannot possibly know the ground of His essence, given the inadequacy of ourselves and of our powers, faculties and instruments of discernment. For this reason, if you study all the books of empirical science, you will not find the slightest mention of an experiment concerning God or any judgment offered concerning God. Even if we do regard sense perception as the only means for discovering reality, we cannot prove, relying on sense perception, that nothing exists beyond the world of the senses. Such an assertion would, in itself, be non-empirical, resting on no sensory or empirical proof. Even if the followers of a religious school of thought had no proofs for their claim, to conclude firmly and forcibly that non- being reigns beyond the sensory realm would be a non-scientific choice, based on imagination and speculation. Some people try to propagate this fantasy in the garb of science and to present their choice as having been dictated by scientific thought. In the final analysis, however, the denial involved in such an assertion is unworthy of science and philosophy, and even contradicts empirical logic. In The Elementary Principles of Philosophy, Georges Pulitzer says, "To imagine a thing that does not occupy time and space and is immune to change and development is an impossibility." It is plain that these words reflect a way of thought that does not know what it is searching for. If it knew what it was looking for, it would also understand how to look for it. Since the activity of this mode of thought revolves around nature and the sensory realm, it will naturally regard as impossible whatever lies beyond the scope of its activity and the existence of which cannot be proven by way of sensory experiment. It will regard belief in such an entity as contrary to the scientific mode of thought. However, scholars in the natural sciences are confronted with a whole mass of unknowns concerning this very earth and tangible, lifeless matter, even though they are constantly in touch with it (apart from which the material universe, with its countless mysteries and secrets, does not consist simply of this globe on which we live). Such scholars have, then, the right only to say, "Since the supernatural realm lies beyond the scope of my professional tools, I remain silent and cannot utter a denial." How could they permit themselves to make a claim that would necessitate knowledge as extensive as the scheme of the universe, when their knowledge of the total scheme of being is close to zero? What proof exists to substantiate the claim that being is equivalent to matter and that the whole world of being consists of material entities? What scientist rejecting metaphysics has ever been able to found his denial on logic or proof, or to furnish evidence that beyond absolute non-being, nothing exists outside the seen realm? ***** Although science does not explicitly and definitively reject every unknown thing simply because it can have no access to it by means of its tools and instruments, patiently awaiting instead the day when it should be discovered, materialists do not even approach the question of the existence of God with doubt and hesitation; on the basis of their erroneous and hasty prejudices, they pronounce their judgment that the Creator does not exist. Such persons establish certain criteria and standards for themselves and are not prepared to apply a different criterion established for a definite purpose in a given area. For example, they would never use the criteria applicable to a surface to measure a body, but when it comes to measuring the supra-sensory world, they try to measure God, the spirit, and inspiration, with the same tools they use to measure the material world. When they find themselves unable to gain any knowledge of the entities in question, they proceed to deny their existence. Now, if a person imprisoned in empirical logic desires to accept the reality of the universe only to the extent permitted him by sensory experience and to deny whatever lies beyond that, he must recognize that this is a path he has chosen for himself; it is not the result of scientific investigation and experiment. This kind of pseudo-intellectualism arises from intellectual rebellion and an abandonment of one's original nature. The god that the natural scientist wishes vainly to "prove" with his tools and instruments is, in any event, no god at all in the view of those who worship God. Lesson 3: God and Empirical Logic

Science is about truth. At least, some kinds of truth: its success lies in focusing on material, factual, reproducible truths. Science has been so astoundingly successful in that limited arena that we moderns assume it is the only kind of truth worth having. It’s an important distinction, because we try to force everything else into the same materialist mold as science, and often act as if poetry and politics, ethics and emotions are either true or not true in the same way it’s true that you and I are made of protons, neutrons, and electrons, and not truethat the world is flat. We value honesty in people, and probably with very few exceptions we each one of us perceive ourselves as honest. But people are complicated. Walt Whitman wisely wrote, “Do I contradict myself? Very well, then I contradict myself, I am large, I contain multitudes.” But nearly two centuries after Whitman’s birth, we have become uncomfortable with contradictions, not only within scientific fact, but with the personal, the metaphorical. While for centuries people were mostly unfazed by contradictions in the Bible (with no small irony, the Scholastic movement of the late Middle Ages, which sought to iron out those contradictions, laid the logical foundation for modern science), today people lose their mind if a movie based upon a comic book differs in modest detail from the source material. While Whitman contained multitudes, a more recent spokesman for our braver newer age, Dr. Gregory House, bluntly stated, Everybody lies. To some extent that’s true–we lie to our loved ones, we lie to ourselves–and yet it’s also trying to impose a rigid, science-inspired, axiomatic framework on goopy, non-axiomatic people, House being a premiere example of that attitude.

I think it's helpful to think of science as "knowledge" rather than a certain method of obtaining knowledge--because there is more than one way of getting information than simply relying on "the scientific method." I'm a science teacher; I teach the scientific method; so, I'm aware of its weaknesses. Etymologically, "science" comes from a term that means "to cut." This suggests that science was primarily a means of gaining knowledge--"to know via cutting/dissection"--which makes a lot of sense to me (a physician and science teacher). Historically, however, it has been synonymous with "knowledge," the end goal of the scientific pursuit. The primacy of science as knowledge over science as method can be seen in how theology used to be called "the queen of the sciences." Theology has never been known to be an experimental endeavor. It's all about knowing, not doing. Theology could never have been called a science unless it were thought of as a noun (a kind of knowledge) instead of a verb (a means of obtaining knowledge). This all goes to say that experiential/experimental data is not the only way of obtaining truth. One must rely on second-hand knowledge--knowledge given to us from reliable sources--almost all the time. Even scientists rely on data given to them from other scientists. As proof, think of this: if one were never to trust authorities, a person would have to redo every important experiment himself. Obviously, this would never be possible.

Science begins with curiosity and is an endless pursuit to explain the world around us.  That inquisitive look on a child's face demonstrates an innate capacity for scientific thought.  If that capacity is encouraged and that child learns a rigorous and systematic process for questioning the world, she or he will become a scientist: a person who engages in scientific thought.  Modern science has also become a social endeavor and human industry in which the best and brightest engage similar minds in the production of new, testable ideas for subsequent research.  This is not to say the average person cannot think scientifically.  We all have the capacity to rationally question our world, though some of us do have greater influence than others.  When that influence is coupled with ground-breaking ideas, revolutions in scientific thought can occur upon which subsequent new technologies and industries can be based. That is science.  It is an innate human capacity refined by education, sharpened by social competition as well as cooperation, and is the hallmark of free thinking societies worldwide.  It is the best method we currently have of understanding our world and our universe.  Through science we shine a light on the unknown, replace awe with actionable data, and increase our collective knowledge.

This understanding can be pursued by direct observation of how things behave under different circumstances, forming hypotheses about why things behave the way they do, and creating experiments attempting to disprove those hypotheses. A theory that we haven't been able to disprove may be considered a scientific fact until proven otherwise. A key rigor of science is repeatability. Any scientific data should be able to be replicated by anyone with the resources to do the experiment or observation, and the conclusions should be reasonable to all objective people. This definition tends to separate "hard" sciences, such as chemistry and physics, from "soft" sciences such as psychology or political science. In the latter, there are so many factors and variables that observations are often difficult to repeat and conclusions are hard to make in any absolute sense.

Science is what someone using the scientific method does. They start with observation of data. They develop a hypothesis to explain the data. The more data the hypothesis explains with the fewer assumptions, the more robust hypothesis. They try to disprove the hypothesis. This is important. You can never definitively prove a hypothesis. In this sense all scientific knowledge carries a degree of uncertainty. Your experiment can take the general form of “If the hypothesis is true, then if we do A we would expect B. If you do A and you get B, then you have failed to prove your hypothesis false, and you can conduct another experiment. You make results known so that others can criticize and benefit from your experiment. Science is inherently a communal project. If not disproven, over time the hypothesis may be refined and treated as a theory. Note that Einstein did not base his famous theories on experimental data, but on thought experiments. His explanations were valued because of their simplicity and robustness. Years or decades later experiments were devised to test them. Darwin did not really conduct experiments. Rather, he gathered massive amounts of data and developed a few simple principles to explain them all. New data continue to support his explanation. The amazing thing with Darwin is that genetics was unknown when he wrote The Origin of Species. He did not know the device through which evolution worked, but he explained how it worked.
